heisig_chinese_memo: I've heard of people having hair on the back of their hands, but this is ridiculous! That's not hair, that's fur!
heisig_story: This character simply reverses the direction of the final stroke of hand to produce fur. If you reverse your hand and put its palm down, you will have the side on which fur grows.

koohiiStory2: Be careful not to pet a cat the wrong way - most cats donÂ´t like you rubbing your hand backwards over their fur.

WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: Fur and fur are the same as each other, so the meaning of this kanji should be simple. This can also mean hair, too, though more like furry hair.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Just make sure you're studying your radicals, otherwise it won't be as simple as I'd hoped.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: With fur, wisp your imagination to a land where there are stalks of fur all around, just like a big tall grassy field (except instead of grass, itâ€™s fur). Youâ€™re surrounded by the black fur, the wind is blowing. Imagine yourself touching the long fur and smelling it. What does it feel / smell like? Now itâ€™s time to get rid of it. Thereâ€™s just too much hair! To get rid of it, youâ€™ll need to mow (ã‚‚ã†) it down with a lawn mower. Imagine yourself starting up the lawn mower, and taking it around, mowing down the hair. Hear the sound of the mower in your head (theyâ€™re loud and distinct). The important thing is to imagine yourself mowing everything. Key is to think â€œfur â†’ In the fur â†’ getting rid of the fur â†’ mow the fur,â€ in that order. Thatâ€™ll get you to mow, which will help you to remember the onâ€™yomi.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Smell the fur as you mow it down. Feel it flying everywhere. It's giant, so it must be pretty intense. Make it more intense to help yourself to remember the reading of this kanji better.

chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: I've heard of people having hair on the back of their hands, but this is ridiculous! That's not hair, that's fur!
origin_of_ch_char_book: (å°¾, wei, tail) combines a person and some sort of ornament (æ¯›, mao, hair; fur) behind him. A person has something hanging behind him. Now this symbol means â€œtailâ€. Even in the present times, there are nomadic tribes. Some of these people live in hot climates. They usually wear simple coverings made out of leaves. Such covering looks like a tail from the back. In the olden days, China was warmer than today, and people who lived in the middle and southern areas of China could have worn such simple clothing.
humanum_full_description_en:
Like hair or animal hair, followed by radicals of Chinese characters. "Shuowen": "Mao, the genus of eyebrows and animal hair. Pictogram. All the genus of hair comes from hair."

The inscription " hair " resembles the hair of humans and animals. It is drawn vertically or decorated with dots, such as a hanging pan. The additional dots in the Warring States characters are extended to short horizontal lines, such as the glyphs such as Shangbo Jian or Baoshan Chu Jian.

The inscription " Mao " was used as the name of the country. Prince Wen, Uncle Mao, was named to Mao, and later named " Mao " in Yiyang County, Henan Province. Ban Gui: "Wang ordered Mao Bai (Bo) to change (Geng) Guocheng public service." It means that Wang ordered Mao Bai to succeed Guocheng government. " Mao " can also be used as a person's name, calling Bo Mao Li: "Call Bai (Bo) Mao Zha (as) Queen Mother Zun Li." In addition, the inscription " Mao " can be read as "æ—„", referring to the yak tail on the top of the flagpole. Ornaments made. For example, the "Mao Liang" in the Ming Xi Ding can make this solution.

Due to the fact that the hair is very finely fragmented, the word "æ¯›" has a subtle meaning according to its characteristics, such as capillary and drizzle.
humanum_short_description_en: " Mao " is like human hair and beast feathers.

Like hair or animal hair, followed by radicals of Chinese characters. "Shuowen": "Mao, the genus of eyebrows and animal hair. Pictogram. All the genus of hair comes from hair." The inscription " hair" resembles the hair of humans and animals. It is drawn vertically or decorated with dots, such as a hanging pan. The additional dots in the Warring States characters are extended to short horizontal lines, such as the glyphs such as Shangbo Jian or Baoshan Chu Jian. The inscription " Mao" was used as the name of the country. Prince Wen, Uncle Mao, was named to Mao, and later named " Mao" in Yiyang County, Henan Province. Ban Gui: "Wang ordered Mao Bai (Bo) to change (Geng) Guocheng public service." It means that Wang ordered Mao Bai to succeed Guocheng government. " Mao" can also be used as a person's name, calling Bo Mao Li: "Call Bai (Bo) Mao Zha (as) Queen Mother Zun Li." In addition, the inscription " Mao" can be read as " æ—„", referring to the yak tail on the top of the flagpole. Ornaments made. For example, the "Mao Liang" in the Ming Xi Ding can make this solution. Due to the fact that the hair is very finely fragmented, the word " æ¯›" has a subtle meaning according to its characteristics, such as capillary and drizzle.

Chinese dictionary definition of words
[â‘ ]ï¼»mÃ¡oï¼½ï¼»mÃ oï¼½
["Guangyun" Mo Paoqie, Pinghao, Ming. ]
["Guang Yun" don't report to cut, go to the number, Ming. ]
(1) The filaments that grow on the epidermis of the human body, animals and plants; the feathers of birds and poultry.
(2) Specifically refers to beard and hair.
(3) By means of beasts.
(4) Refers to furry animal skins.
(5) (also read mÃ o) means to choose the coat color of the livestock.
(6) Dehairing. See "Mao Yan".
(7) Refers to plants growing on the ground. Refers to crops.
(8) Especially refers to the mold growing on the object. They are mostly filamentous and clumped.
(9) The metaphors are numerous and fragmented. See "Mao Qi", "Mao Qi".
(10) Small and insignificant. Mostly used in derogatory sense.
(11) Unprocessed; rough.
(12) Fuzzy. Multi-fingered objects.
(13) Rough; impure.
(14) Rough, not careful. See "hands and feet".
(15) None.
(16) Dialects. Said currency depreciation.
(17) See "Mao waist".
(18) It is called panic.
(19) Adverbs. About; about touch.
(20) Through "yak". Yak tail.
(21) Dialects. Angry, angry.
(22) Names of ancient weapons.
(23) The common name of the Chinese currency "corner".
(24) Chinese medical terminology. Refers to a more floating pulse condition.
(25) The name of the benefice in Zhouji. Ji
